topic_seeds.description: Struggling with social situations and fear of judgment (relatively straightforward)

exchanges.user:
So I've been thinking about reaching out for a while now, and honestly I'm not even sure where to start. I guess that's the whole thing though, isn't it? Like, there's so much rattling around in my head that I don't know which thread to pull first.

Work has been... it's been a lot. I'm in this weird position where I've been offered this promotion, which sounds like it should be great, right? But the money's actually not much better when you factor in the stress, and the role would basically mean I'm managing people and sitting in meetings all day instead of doing the actual work I'm good at. And I keep going back and forth on it. Some days I think "just take it, you're 55, you need the security," and other days I think "you'll hate it, you know you will, so why are you even considering it?"

But that's not even the thing that's really bugging me, if I'm being honest. It's more that... I don't know. I feel like I can't do anything right lately. I'll have a good morning, feel okay, and then something small happens—like my daughter doesn't text back right away, or I notice a mistake in something I did—and suddenly I'm in this hole. And it's not reasonable. I *know* it's not reasonable. But knowing that doesn't really help, you know? It just makes me feel worse about feeling bad.

Anyway, I'm rambling. I just... I thought it might help to talk to someone who isn't going to judge me for being a mess or tell me to just "think positive."
exchanges.assistant:
I'm really glad you reached out. That thing you said about not knowing which thread to pull—that makes complete sense when you're holding this many at once. Let me try to reflect what I'm hearing, and we can figure out together what feels most pressing.

**The promotion decision:** This sounds less like indecision and more like you're hearing two very real voices. One voice worked toward this role, sees security, knows you're 55 and that matters. The other voice knows what drains you—meetings, managing people, being pulled away from work you're actually good at. And the money doesn't even offset that. That's not you being flaky. That's wisdom trying to surface. I wonder: if the security piece wasn't weighing on you, what would the answer be?

**The spiral thing—feeling okay, then crashing over small stuff:** You said something really important: "knowing it's not reasonable doesn't help, it just makes me feel worse about feeling bad." That's the double-bind, right? You're not just feeling bad, you're judging yourself *for* feeling bad, which makes the hole deeper. What if the goal isn't to stop the spiral, but to notice it happening without adding the layer of "I shouldn't feel this way"? Like, "Oh, there's that hole again. It showed up because my daughter didn't text back. My brain does this." Not because you're broken, but because your brain is trying to protect you from something—maybe rejection, maybe failure, maybe something else. What do you think it might be protecting you from?

**The bigger picture—"I can't do anything right lately":** This one worries me a little, because it sounds like you're collecting evidence for a story your mind is telling: "I'm a mess." But you also just told me you're good at your actual work, you're thoughtful enough to recognize when a feeling is disproportionate, and you're showing up here trying to figure this out. That's not nothing. When did this "I can't do anything right" story start feeling so loud?

You're not rambling. You're making sense. And you're not a mess—you're someone dealing with a real decision, a real pattern, and a brain that's working overtime. Let's start with what feels most urgent to you: the job decision, the spiral pattern, or something else?

exchanges.user:
Been a few days and honestly I've been all over the place. Like, the promotion thing came up again in a meeting and my boss asked point-blank what I was thinking, and I just... froze. Couldn't commit either way. He seemed annoyed, which of course made me spiral a bit. So that's still unresolved and now it feels more urgent and I hate that.

But the thing you said about my brain protecting me from something—I've been turning that over. I think it might actually be rejection, or like, failing in front of people? Because when my daughter doesn't text back I immediately go to "she's mad at me" or "I did something wrong," not "she's busy." And at work when I make a small error on something, I catastrophize it like it means I'm incompetent. Which is ridiculous because I've been doing this job well for years.

The weird thing is I had a genuinely good few days mid-week. Like, really good. My mom called and we had this lovely conversation—she was being supportive about everything, not critical like she usually is—and I felt lighter. Made it through Thursday feeling okay. Then Friday hit and it was like someone flipped a switch. I was irritable, exhausted, couldn't focus. Nothing specific happened, it just... shifted. And now I'm back to feeling kind of flat and anxious.

Does that happen to other people? This mood thing where it just swings without a clear reason? I feel like I'm going crazy some days.
exchanges.assistant:
**The promotion pressure:** You didn't freeze because you're indecisive—you froze because neither option feels right yet, and being pushed to commit before you're ready is legitimately hard. Your boss's annoyance doesn't mean you owe him an answer faster than you can get clear on what you actually want. What if you bought yourself a little time? Something like: "I'm taking this seriously and want to make the right call—can I get back to you by [specific date]?" That's not stalling, that's being deliberate. And it might give you room to figure out which voice (the security one or the "you'll hate this" one) is actually steering.

**The rejection/failure thing—yes, that's landing:** You just mapped the pattern perfectly: daughter doesn't text → "she's mad at me." Small work error → "I'm incompetent." Your brain skips right past the neutral explanations (she's busy, mistakes happen) and lands on the version where you failed someone or let them down. That's not ridiculous—that's your threat system doing exactly what it evolved to do, which is scan for danger. The danger it's scanning for is social rejection or being seen as not-enough. Makes sense that your boss seeming annoyed triggered the same thing: "I disappointed him, I'm failing." 

Here's something to try: Next time you notice that jump (small thing → catastrophe), pause and ask yourself: "What's the evidence for this thought? And what's the evidence against it?" Not to talk yourself out of the feeling, but to see if your brain is offering you a story or a fact. You've been doing your job well for years—that's evidence. Your daughter has been busy before and it wasn't about you—that's evidence. Let's track whether naming the pattern gives you any distance from it.

**The mood swing—Thursday great, Friday awful, no clear trigger:** Yes, this happens to other people. You're not going crazy. Moods can shift for reasons that aren't obvious in the moment: sleep quality, hormonal fluctuations (especially in perimenopause if that's relevant for you), how much you ate, even how much sunlight you got. Sometimes there's no satisfying "why," and that lack of explanation can itself feel destabilizing. 

But here's what I'm noticing: Thursday you had connection (good call with your mom, she was supportive instead of critical) and you felt lighter. Friday you felt irritable and flat. I wonder if part of what makes the good days good is feeling seen and supported, and part of what makes the hard days hard is feeling alone in it. Does that resonate? And when you say "flat and anxious"—what does that feel like in your body? Where do you notice it?

exchanges.user:
Okay so I actually did the thing you suggested—the "pause and ask what's the evidence" thing—and it's been... weird? Like, I notice myself doing it now, which is good, but also it's exhausting? I'll catch myself spiraling about something my coworker said and I'm like "okay, evidence for, evidence against," and half the time I can talk myself down. But the other half I'm just sitting there arguing with myself and it doesn't actually make me feel better, it just makes me aware that I'm doing this ridiculous thing my brain does. So maybe that's progress, I don't know.

Anyway, bigger update: I actually called my boss back. Told him I needed until next Friday to decide on the promotion, and he said fine. Which was anticlimactic, honestly—I was bracing for him to be annoyed again but he just... wasn't. So now I have a week to actually think about this instead of just spiraling about it, which is something.

The mood thing though. I've been paying more attention like you asked, and it's VERY obvious when I feel less alone versus when I don't. Wednesday my friend Susan came over and we just sat and talked for like two hours, and I was fine. Genuinely fine. But then yesterday I had this day where I barely left the house and didn't really talk to anyone meaningful, and by evening I was feeling that flat, anxious thing again. So like... is that the whole answer? Just don't be alone? Because that feels impossible most days. I can't manufacture deep conversation with people whenever I need it. And I hate feeling dependent on other people's attention to not feel like garbage.
exchanges.assistant:
**The evidence technique—noticing but exhausting:** That's actually exactly how it's supposed to work at first. You're building a new muscle, and right now it takes conscious effort. The fact that you're catching yourself mid-spiral is huge—that's the awareness piece, and it comes before the shift in how you feel. Half the time you can talk yourself down, half the time you're just arguing with your brain and it doesn't help. That ratio will probably improve with practice, but here's the thing: even when it doesn't "work," you're still interrupting the automatic spiral. You're creating a gap between the thought and the reaction. That gap matters, even when it feels ridiculous in the moment.

One tweak that might help when you're stuck arguing with yourself: instead of debating whether the thought is true, try just labeling it. "There's the 'I'm incompetent' thought again." Not agreeing with it, not fighting it—just noticing it like you'd notice a car driving by. Sometimes that creates more distance than trying to logic your way out.

**The promotion deadline—you bought yourself time:** And your boss was fine with it. Which tells you something, right? The urgency you were feeling wasn't coming from him, it was coming from your own discomfort with uncertainty. Now you have a week. So let's use it. Here's a question that might help you get clearer: Imagine it's a year from now and you took the promotion. What does a Tuesday look like? Not the highlight reel—just a normal Tuesday. What are you doing, who are you talking to, what's draining you, what's not? Now imagine you didn't take it. Same question: what does that Tuesday look like? Which version feels more like a life you actually want to live?

**Feeling fine with Susan, flat alone—and hating the dependency:** Yes, connection is part of the answer. But "just don't be alone" isn't the takeaway, because you're right—you can't manufacture deep conversation on demand, and depending on other people's availability to regulate your mood feels shitty and unsustainable. So let's separate two things: (1) You feel better when you're connected to people you care about. That's not a weakness, that's being human. (2) You also need ways to feel okay when you're alone, because being alone is going to happen.

Here's something to try this week: When you notice that flat, anxious feeling creeping in and you're by yourself, do one small thing that mimics connection or care. Call someone and leave a voicemail (you don't have to talk, just hearing your own voice reaching out can help). Text a friend something low-stakes. Or try this—write a few sentences to yourself like you're talking to a friend: "Hey, I see you're feeling flat right now. That makes sense. You've had a long day." Sounds cheesy, but you're essentially giving yourself the thing you'd get from Susan: being seen. Worth experimenting with?

exchanges.user:
So I actually tried the voicemail thing and it felt... awkward? Like I called my own number and left this message trying to be nice to myself and I just cringed listening to it back. But also it kind of worked? I don't know. I felt a little less alone after doing it, which is strange because it was literally just me talking to me. Anyway, I'm still trying to figure out the whole connection thing.

The bigger news is I've been thinking hard about the promotion, like you suggested—the "what does a Tuesday look like" exercise. And honestly? When I imagine myself in that role sitting in meetings all day, managing people, dealing with politics... I feel tired just thinking about it. But when I imagine staying where I am, I feel relieved. Genuinely relieved. Which I guess means the answer is no, but then why do I feel guilty about saying no? Like I'm supposed to want this. I'm supposed to be ambitious or whatever. My mom mentioned when I called her that "you'd be foolish to turn down security at your age," which didn't help. She meant well but it just landed like "you're making the wrong choice." So now I'm second-guessing myself again, even though I know what I actually want.

Also my mood has been all over the place this week. Monday and Tuesday were okay, Wednesday was rough—woke up feeling anxious for no reason. But then Thursday I had coffee with Susan again and felt fine the rest of the day. Yesterday back to feeling kind of empty. It's like I can see the pattern now but seeing it doesn't really change it. Does that make sense?
exchanges.assistant:
**The voicemail experiment—awkward but it worked:** That cringe you felt? That's actually really common when we first try self-compassion stuff. Your brain isn't used to hearing you talk to yourself with kindness, so it flags it as weird or fake. But the fact that you felt a little less alone afterward—that's the signal. The awkwardness might fade with practice, or it might not, and that's fine. The question is: did it give you something useful? Sounds like it did, even if it felt strange. You don't have to love the tool for it to work.

**The promotion decision—you know the answer:** You just told me. When you imagine the role, you feel tired. When you imagine staying, you feel relieved. That's your body giving you clarity. The guilt isn't about the decision—it's about the story you think you're supposed to follow: "be ambitious," "don't turn down security," "you're 55, you should want this." But those are other people's values, not necessarily yours. Your mom's comment landed hard because it tapped into that fear: "What if I'm making the wrong choice? What if I regret this?" 

Here's the thing: saying no to this promotion isn't saying no to security or ambition. It's saying yes to doing work you're good at, work that doesn't drain you. That's not foolish—that's knowing yourself. And if security is genuinely a concern, there are other ways to build it that don't involve a role that makes you tired just thinking about it. What would it feel like to trust that relief you felt? To let that be the answer?

One thing that might help with the guilt: imagine a friend came to you with this exact situation. They're offered a promotion that pays slightly more but means meetings all day and managing people. When they imagine it, they feel tired. When they imagine staying, they feel relieved. What would you say to them? Would you tell them they're foolish, or would you say "sounds like you know what you need"?

**Mood pattern—you can see it now, but it's not changing yet:** Yes, that makes complete sense. Awareness is the first step, not the solution. You're noticing: connection (coffee with Susan) = feel fine. Alone + anxious morning = rough day. That's huge information. But knowing the pattern doesn't automatically fix it, because you can't control when Susan is free or when your brain decides to wake up anxious. So what do we do with the pattern now that you can see it?

Two things to try: First, on days when you wake up feeling anxious for no reason, acknowledge it out loud: "Okay, my nervous system is activated. This isn't about anything real happening right now." Then do something small and concrete—make coffee, take a short walk, text one person. Not to fix the anxiety, but to give your body a signal that you're safe and moving. Second, when you have a good day (like Thursday after coffee), notice what else was present besides Susan. Did you sleep okay? Eat breakfast? Get outside? Sometimes connection is the main thing, but sometimes there are smaller variables stacking up that we miss.

Does the pattern feel more predictable now that you're tracking it, or does it still feel random?

exchanges.user:
So I've been sitting with the promotion thing and I think I'm ready to tell my boss no. Which feels both relieving and terrifying, honestly. Like intellectually I know it's the right call but there's this voice that keeps saying "you're going to regret this, you'll need that money someday." But I also know my mom's voice is in there too, so. Anyway, I'm going to do it. Probably next week. I keep saying "next week" but I mean it this time.

On the mood front—I've been trying to do those small things you mentioned when I wake up anxious, and some days it helps. Yesterday morning I woke up with that tight chest feeling and I just sat with it for like ten minutes instead of immediately spiraling into "what's wrong with me," and eventually it passed. So that was good. But then today I didn't even get out of bed until almost noon because I just felt so empty and tired, and all the "do something concrete" advice kind of went out the window. I couldn't motivate myself to do anything. It wasn't anxiety—it was more like... nothing matters? Which is different than the spiral feeling. Is that a different thing or is it the same thing with a different flavor?

Also I realized I've been putting a lot on Susan, like expecting her to be my emotional support person, and I feel kind of embarrassed about that now. She probably has her own stuff going on. So I'm trying not to text her as much, which I know is probably good boundaries or whatever, but now I'm back to feeling isolated again. I can't seem to find the middle ground between "lean on people too much" and "don't lean on them at all." Everything feels like I'm doing it wrong.
exchanges.assistant:
**The promotion decision—you're ready to say no:** That relief you feel? Trust it. The terror is real too—it's your brain running through worst-case scenarios because saying no to something means closing a door, and closed doors feel risky. But here's what I'm noticing: you keep saying "next week" not because you're avoiding the conversation, but because you're still wrestling with your mom's voice ("you'll need that money someday") versus what you actually know about yourself (this role would drain you). That's not procrastination—that's your system trying to reconcile two competing truths. 

What if you separated those? Truth one: Financial security matters, especially at 55. That's valid. Truth two: This specific promotion isn't the only path to security, and it comes with costs you can feel in your body when you imagine it. Both can be true. Saying no to this role doesn't mean you're saying no to security—it means you're saying no to *this version* of security at *this cost*. If money is genuinely a concern, we can talk about other ways to build that (staying in your current role and picking up a side project, negotiating a raise where you are, cutting expenses). But the promotion itself? Sounds like you already know.

When you do tell your boss, keep it simple: "I've thought about it and I'm going to stay in my current role. I appreciate the offer." You don't owe him the internal wrestling match. And after you say it, notice what happens in your body—my guess is that relief will get louder than the terror.

**The mood differences—anxious chest tightness vs. empty/tired/nothing matters:** Yes, these are different. The anxiety (tight chest, spiral, "what's wrong with me") is your nervous system in overdrive—threat mode, scanning for danger. What you're describing today (couldn't get out of bed, felt empty, "nothing matters") sounds more like shutdown mode, or what some people call "low mood" or depression. It's not the same flavor, it's a different state entirely. Anxiety is the gas pedal stuck down; this is the brake pedal stuck down. Both are your nervous system trying to cope, but they need different responses.

When you're anxious, grounding and movement help (like you did yesterday—sitting with the tight chest until it passed, that was perfect). When you're in shutdown mode (empty, exhausted, "nothing matters"), forcing yourself to "do something concrete" can feel impossible because your system is conserved, not activated. On those days, the goal isn't to motivate yourself into action—it's to do the absolute smallest thing that requires almost no energy. Not "get out of bed and go for a walk." More like: "sit up," then "put feet on floor," then "stand for ten seconds." Sometimes just making coffee is the win. No judgment for staying in bed until noon—your body was telling you it needed rest or protection from something. What do you think it might have been protecting you from?

**Susan and the leaning-too-much fear—you've swung to the opposite extreme:** You noticed you were leaning on Susan a lot, felt embarrassed, so now you're pulling back and feeling isolated again. But here's the thing: you didn't actually ask Susan if it was too much. You decided for her that it was, and now you're in "don't lean on them at all" mode to avoid the risk of being too much. That's not boundaries—that's withdrawing to protect yourself from potential rejection.

The middle ground you're looking for isn't "figure out the exact right amount to text Susan." It's this: reach out when you need connection, and trust that if it's too much, she'll tell you. Most friendships can hold more than you think. And if you're worried, you could just ask her directly: "Hey, I've been leaning on you a lot lately and I appreciate it. Let me know if I'm overdoing it—I don't want to be too much." Chances are she'll say you're fine. And if she does need space, she'll tell you, and that's okay too. But right now you're managing a problem that doesn't exist yet, and in doing so, you're cutting yourself off from the thing that actually helps (connection).

You're not doing everything wrong. You're learning to notice patterns (anxiety vs. shutdown, connection helps, your mom's voice vs. yours). That's hard work, and you're doing it. The "wrong" feeling is part of the learning curve—it means you're trying new things and they don't feel automatic yet. Give it time.

exchanges.user:
Been a couple days and honestly I'm feeling kind of raw right now. I did tell my boss no on the promotion—just said it simple like you suggested, "I've thought about it and I'm staying in my current role," and he just nodded and said okay. No drama. And you were right about the relief, it's definitely there, but underneath it there's this weird guilt that won't quit. Like I made the "safe" choice instead of the "brave" choice and now I'm supposed to feel good about that but mostly I just feel like I took the coward's way out. I know that's my mom's voice talking but knowing it doesn't really shut it up, you know?

Anyway, that's not even the main thing. I texted Susan like you said—asked her straight up if I was being too much—and she was like "are you kidding, I love talking to you, keep texting." Which should have felt good but instead I felt this rush of shame that I'd even questioned it. Like I was bad for doubting her. And then I felt grateful in this way that felt almost desperate? I don't know how to describe it. It was confusing.

But here's what's really bothering me: yesterday I woke up in that shutdown mode again, the empty feeling, and I couldn't get myself to do anything. Not even the small stuff. And it lasted all day. By evening I was thinking things like "what's the point of any of this" which I know isn't good. I didn't hurt myself or anything but it scared me a little, how dark it got. It came out of nowhere too—I'd had a fine day Thursday, nothing bad happened. It's like my brain just decided to go there. Is this something I should be worried about? Should I be talking to a doctor about this instead of just here?
exchanges.assistant:
**The promotion decision—relief mixed with guilt:** You did it. You told your boss no, and he was fine with it. No drama, just "okay." But now you're sitting with this guilt story: "I took the coward's way out, I chose safe over brave." Let's look at that for a second. What if saying no to a role that would have drained you—when the easier path would have been to just say yes and collect the slight pay bump—what if *that* was the brave choice? It takes more courage to disappoint people's expectations (your mom's, your own internal "shoulds") than to just follow the script. You listened to what your body was telling you and you honored it. That's not cowardice. That's self-knowledge.

Your mom's voice is loud right now because you just made a choice she wouldn't have made, and some part of you is bracing for her judgment (real or imagined). But here's the thing: you don't need her permission to make the right choice for your life. The guilt will probably hang around for a bit—it doesn't just vanish because you know intellectually where it's coming from. But every day you stay in the role you actually want, the relief will get a little louder and the guilt will get a little quieter. Give it time.

**Susan's response and the shame/desperate gratitude combo:** She said "keep texting," and instead of just feeling good about it, you felt shame for doubting her and then this desperate kind of gratitude. That makes complete sense, and here's why: you were bracing for rejection ("I'm too much"), and when she gave you the opposite (reassurance, affection), your nervous system didn't know what to do with it. Shame showed up because you'd pre-emptively decided you were a burden, and her response made you realize you'd gotten it wrong—so now you're embarrassed for doubting her. And the desperate gratitude is your system flooding with relief that you're not being rejected after all. It's not bad that you felt those things—it's information. It tells me that connection feels high-stakes for you right now, like you're always one step away from being too much or not enough. Does that land?

One thing to try: next time someone reassures you like that, see if you can just say "thank you" and let it be simple. Not "thank you I'm sorry for asking" or "thank you I'm so grateful you don't hate me"—just "thank you." Let yourself receive the reassurance without adding layers of shame or desperation on top of it. It's a practice.

**The dark thoughts—"what's the point of any of this":** First: I'm glad you told me about this, and I'm glad you noticed it scared you. That awareness matters. Yes, this is something to take seriously. When your mood drops into "what's the point" territory and it lasts all day, and especially when it feels like it came out of nowhere, that's worth paying attention to. It doesn't mean you're in crisis right now, but it does mean your brain went to a dark place and you felt scared by it—and that's a signal.

Here's what I want you to do: If those thoughts come back, or if they get more specific (like thoughts about hurting yourself, or a plan, or feeling like people would be better off without you), I need you to reach out to someone—a doctor, a crisis line, a friend, someone. You mentioned you didn't hurt yourself, which is good, but "what's the point of any of this" can be a stepping stone to darker places, and I don't want you sitting alone with that if it escalates.

For right now, though: yes, I think it's worth talking to a doctor or therapist about these mood swings—the anxiety spikes, the shutdown days, the dark thoughts that come out of nowhere. What you're describing (good day Thursday, then Friday your brain just "decided to go there") sounds like it could be more than just situational stress. It could be something like depression cycling with anxiety, or a hormonal piece (if you're perimenopausal, that can absolutely cause mood instability), or just your nervous system getting overwhelmed and shutting down. A doctor can help you figure out if there's a biological component here—something like an SSRI or therapy might help stabilize things so you're not riding this rollercoaster every week.

You asked if you should be talking to a doctor instead of just here. Here's my answer: you can do both. I'm here for support and exploration and helping you make sense of patterns. But if your mood is dropping into "what's the point" and it's scaring you, that's beyond what coaching alone should handle. You deserve more support than just me. Does that feel doable—reaching out to a doctor or therapist this week?

exchanges.user:
Been a few days and I'm not even sure where to start, honestly. So I did call my doctor—like actually picked up the phone and made an appointment, which felt like a big thing for me. It's next Thursday. I told her on the phone that I've been having mood swings and some dark thoughts, and she didn't seem alarmed exactly but she was taking it seriously, which helped. So that's happening. I'm nervous about it but also relieved someone else is going to look at this with me.

The thing is, between now and then I'm kind of in this holding pattern? Like I know something might be off but I don't know if it's depression or hormones or just stress from the promotion decision finally being over. Yesterday morning I woke up okay, felt almost normal for the first time in a while. But then I got a work email from my boss asking me to take on this extra project (separate from the promotion thing) and my immediate thought was "he's testing me to see if I made the wrong choice turning down the role." Which is probably not what's happening, right? But I couldn't shake it. Ended up texting Susan about it because I didn't want to spiral alone, and she talked me through it, and it helped.

So that worked, I guess. Using the connection thing instead of just white-knuckling through it. But now I'm worried I'm back to leaning on her too much? I hate this. I feel like I can't find the actual balance between "isolate and feel worse" and "lean on people and feel like a burden." It's exhausting even just thinking about it.

Also my mom called yesterday and I didn't pick up. I know I should probably call her back but I'm just... not ready to hear her take on the doctor thing. She'll either make it into something bigger than it is or tell me I'm overreacting. I can't win with her right now.
exchanges.assistant:
**The doctor appointment—you actually did it:** That's huge. Picking up the phone and saying "I need help with this" when you're in the middle of it is hard, and you did it anyway. And your doctor took it seriously without alarming you—that's exactly what you needed. Thursday's coming, and between now and then, yeah, you're in a holding pattern. That's uncomfortable, but it's also temporary. You don't have to figure out if it's depression or hormones or stress right now—that's what Thursday is for. For now, you're allowed to just be in the uncertainty without needing to solve it.

**The work email and the "he's testing me" thought:** Your boss asks you to take on an extra project, and your brain immediately goes to: "This is a test. He's checking if I made the wrong choice." That's the same pattern we've been tracking—your mind skipping past the neutral explanation (he needs help on a project, you're good at your job, he asked you) and landing on the version where you're being judged or you failed. Chances are he just needs someone to do the work and you're capable, so he asked. But your threat system heard: "You said no to the promotion, now prove you're still valuable."

Here's the thing: even if he *is* testing you (which I doubt), that doesn't mean you made the wrong choice. You can be good at your job, take on extra projects when it makes sense, and still have been right to say no to a role that would've drained you. Those things aren't in conflict. What happened when Susan talked you through it? What did she say that helped you get distance from the spiral?

**Leaning on Susan—the worry is back:** You texted her instead of white-knuckling it alone, and it helped. That's exactly what connection is supposed to do. But now the worry's back: "Am I leaning on her too much again?" Let me ask you this: when Susan texted you after you asked if you were being too much, what did she say? She said "keep texting." So you texted her yesterday about the work thing, and she helped. That's not you being a burden—that's her doing exactly what she told you she wanted to do. 

The "balance" you're looking for isn't a formula (text her X times per week but not more than Y). It's this: reach out when you need support, trust that she'll tell you if it's too much, and try to notice when the worry about being too much is louder than any actual signal from her. Right now, the only person saying you're too much is you. Susan isn't saying it.
